awd_abstract_narration:
Irregular or random growth is a ubiquitous phenomenon in nature, occurring in settings ranging from the growth of bacterial colonies and tumors to the formation of coffee rings and the spread of forest fires. The last twenty years have seen a renaissance in our understanding of mathematical models of these phenomena, particularly in two space-time dimensions where many such models are conjectured (and sometimes proven) to have the same statistical properties. This project supports fundamental research into mathematical models of this type, both in the two dimensional settings which have been the focus of much recent work and in higher dimensions where much less is known. In addition to the proposed research, this project includes outreach components aimed at connecting students at levels ranging from middle school to graduate school to fun mathematics in general and to the world of random growth models in particular. 

The PI will study the structure of a class of models at the interface of rigorous statistical mechanics and probability known as random walks in random potentials, both in positive and in zero temperature. This class of models is broad. On the lattice, it includes first passage percolation and directed last passage percolation, directed polymers in random media, as well as random walks in both static and dynamic random environments, with general admissible steps. Continuum models like the continuum directed polymer and the associated stochastic heat equation with multiplicative noise will also be considered. The main goal of this project is to improve our understanding of the infinite volume structure of such models through specific examples and to work toward a unified treatment of that structure in the greatest generality that can be achieved.  Concretely, the main goal of the project will be to characterize the existence and uniqueness properties of semi-infinite and bi-infinite volume measures (respectively geodesics). The work will also consider related problems, including investigating how infinite volume measures relate to the regularity properties of the limiting free energy (respectively shape function), developing computational tools in exactly solvable models and on understanding the structure of the environment viewed from the perspective of paths drawn from the infinite volume measure (respectively a geodesic).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the behavior of a collection of models known as random walks in random potentials which include a large family belonging to the Kardar-Parisi-Zhang (KPZ) universality class. This class is a collection of mathematical models and physical phenomena which are expected to cover the statistical properties of aspects of forest fire propagation, bacterial colony growth, and certain properties of quantum spin transport, among many other examples.The main questions of interest about these models concern their long-term space-time behavior and in particular their statistical properties. The work in this project focused on the structure of stationary distributions (which can be thought of as the typical long-time space behavior) and on the behavior of "geodesics," which one can think of as the path that was taken for a particular point to "burn" in a fire or to "become infected" by the bacterial colony. The behavior of these geodesics are expected (and have been shown in some cases) to encode some of the key statistical properties of this type of phenomena. The key theme of this project was a close relationship between infinite-length geodesic rays and stationary distributions.


The first main research outcome of this project was the completion of the first complete accounting of geodesic rays in any model in the class. The methods used to solve this were general, but their full strength only applied in the exactly solvable model of exponential last-passage percolation, where delicate algebraic structure allows for the verification of otherwise unverified hypotheses which are expected to hold generally. A follow-up project showed that the tools used in that project, known as "generalized Busemann functions" exist very broadly within the class of random walks in random potentials. Indeed, these exist extend far beyond the hypotheses that are believed to characterize the KPZ class. This opens up the possibility that some of these newly developed methods may apply quite generally. Other related results for the general random walk in random potential model were also developed in companion projects.


The KPZ equation is the namesake of the KPZ class and is commonly used as a prototypical model of random interface growth. One of the earliest and most basic predictions about its behavior is that there is only one stationary distribution of the model up to symmetry. The second main research outcome was a rigorous proof (when combined with some follow-up work) of this long-standing prediction. The methods used here are related to those in the previous project, using the relationship between infinite volume Gibbs measures (which are the analogues of geodesics in this setting) and stationary distributions. A companion project also studied the basic structure of the KPZ equation, producing new regularity results about the joint behavior of solutions with different initial conditions run in the same environment.


A third major line of research in this project concerned the development of sharp tail bounds in exactly solvable models. These tail bounds can be thought of as highly accurate estimates of the probability of rare events where either the growing interface is much smaller than it typically is or where certain geodesics deviate strongly from their typical behavior. A new method was introduced which has been shown by other research groups to generalize well to other settings, including some which are not quite exactly solvable.


A fourth main research outcome was the extension of many of the themes discussed above to so-called inhomogeneous models. These are models where the environment in different locations can have different statistical properties, with some regions being more favorable to "burning" or "infection" than others. A basic long-time property known as a shape theorem was proven. This says that there is a typical growth rate. A follow-up project developed the stationary distributions, infinite geodesics, and Busemann functions discussed above in this new setting and showed that inhomogeneity results in qualitatively new behavior. This will form the foundation for future work on inhomogeneous models.


The PI worked with undergraduate students to produce simulations related to several of the projects discussed above. These projects taught students basic probabilistic and statistical computational skills and gave them experience working with high performance computing resources. The PI also worked with several other faculty at Purdue University to found a new teachers' math circle.
